summary: the genus Betacoronavirus is further classified into lineages A to D (3, 5, 6) the genus is now classified into four genera, Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus, and Gammacoronavirus. the genus is now classified into four genera, replacing the traditional three groups, groups 1 to 3 (1–4) bats may be the animal origin of both SARS and MERS epidemics. other animals have served as the intermediate or amplifying hosts for animal-to-human transmission, palm civets in the case of SARS. two SARSr-Rs-BatCoVs, previously designated SARSr-Rh-BatCoVs, shared only 87 to 92% nucleotide identities to human/civet SARSr-CoV genomes. a similar virus, SARSr-Rs-BatCoV WIV1, was able to use angiotensin converting enzyme II (ACE2) from humans, civets, and Chinese horseshoe bats as a diverse CoVs were detected, including two SARS-related Rhinolophus ferrumequinum BatCoVs (SARSr-Rf-BatCoVs) from greater horseshoe bats (R. ferrumequinum), which possessed an expressed ORF8 much more closely related to human/civet SARSr-CoVs. recombination and molecular clock analysis were also performed to elucidate the evolutionary paths and time of interspecies RNA was extracted from alimentary samples using a QIAamp viral RNA minikit. the RNA was eluted in 50 l of AVE buffer and used as the template for reverse transcription (RT)-PCR. RT-PCR was performed by amplifying a 440-bp fragment of the RdRp gene of CoVs. a phylogenetic tree was constructed using 266-bp fragments of the RdRp gene with the maximum likelihood method. phylogenetic tree construction was performed using the maximum likelihood method with MEGA 6.0. sliding window analysis performed using nucleotide alignment of available genome sequences generated by ClustalX version 1.83. similarity plot analysis and Bootscan analysis performed using Simplot version 3.5.1 (49). civet SARSr-CoV SZ3 was the query. cDNA was PCR amplified with a forward primer (5′-CTACCCAGGAAAAGCCAAC-3′) located in the leader sequence and a reverse primer (5′-TGAACCATAGTGTGCCATCT-3′) located in the body of the ORF8 mRNA. RT-PCR products were subjected to agarose gel electrophoresis. the nucleotide and genome sequences of the CoVs detected in this study have been deposited in the GenBank sequence database. the collection of bat samples was approved and performed by the Yunnan Institute of Endemic Diseases Control and Prevention, Dali, Yunnan, China. bat samples were captured from various locations in five counties of four prefectures of Yunnan Province, China. RT-PCR was performed by amplifying a 440-bp fragment of the RdRp gene of CoVs using conserved primers (5′-GGTTGGGACTATCCTAAGTGTGA-3′ and 5′-ACCATCATCATCNGANARDATCATNA-3′) the mixture contained cDNA, PCR buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.3, 50 mM KCl, 3 mM MgCl2, 0.01% ge reversible model with gamma distribution as well as allowance of evolutionarily invariable sites (GTR+G+I) by MEGA 5.0 (47) complete genome sequencing and analysis of SARSr-Rf-BatCoVs. RNA was converted to cDNA by a combined random-priming and oligo(dT) priming strategy. the number of synonymous substitutions per synonymous site, Ks, and the number of nonsynonymous substitutions per nonsynonymous site, Ka, were calculated for all available SARSr-Rf-BatCoV, SARSr-Rs-BatCoV, civet SARSr-CoV, and human SARSr-CoV genomes. the time to most recent common ancestor (tMRCA) was estimated based on an alignment of ORF1 cDNA was PCR amplified with a forward primer (5′-CTACCCAGGAAAAGCCAAC-3′) located in the leader sequence and a reverse primer (5′-TGAACCATAGTGTGCCATCT-3′) located in the body of the ORF8 mRNA. the mixtures were amplified for 60 cycles of 94°C for 1 min, 50°C for 1 min, and 72°C for 1 min and a final extension at 72°C for 10 min RT-PCR for a 440-bp fragment of the RdRp gene of CoVs was positive in alimentary samples from 46 bats of five species belonging to four genera. 35 samples contained diverse alphacoronaviruses, while 11 samples contained betacoronaviruses, including two lineage B betacoronaviruses. un Rs-BatCoV HKU2 (1) 93 Mojiang Rs-BatCoV HKU2 (1) 93 Mojiang Rs-BatCoV HKU7 (2) 96 Mojiang Mi-BatCoV HKU8 (1) 96 Mojiang Rousettus leschenaulti Leschenault's rousette 115 9 Ro-BatCoV HKU9 (9) 75–79 Mengla Unknown 19 0 Detection of diverse bat alphacorona two sequences from Hipposideros pomona in Mojiang possessed 96% nucleotide identities to Miniopterus bat CoV HKU10 (Hi-BatCoV HKU10) (GenBank accession no. SARSr-Rf-BatCoVs from greater horseshoe bats instead of SARSr-Rs-BatCoV from Chinese horseshoe bats. civet SARSr-CoV SZ3 was shown to have much higher sequence similarities to SARSr-Rf-BatCoVs within ORF8 than to SARSr-Rs-BatCoVs within ORF8. a gapless nucleotide alignment was generated with ClustalX. bases conserved between civet SARSr-CoV SZ03 and SARSr-Rf-BatCoVs (strains YNLF_31C and Rf1) are marked in green boxes. the 29-nt deletion in human SARS coronavirus TOR2 is highlighted in orange. another region of interest was S, which was situated between two breakpoints at positions 20900 and 26100. positive selection was particularly strong at the S (Ka/Ks = 3) and ORF3 (Ka/Ks = 2) regions of civet SARSr-CoVs and the M (Ka/Ks = 2) and ORF8 (Ka/Ks = 3.5) regions of human SARS-CoVs. 2002.6). the leader TRS and the ORF8 subgenomic mRNA exactly matched each other. the leader TRS and the ORF8 subgenomic mRNA exactly matched each other. the leader TRS was confirmed as the first 66 nt of the genome. t SARSr-CoV and SARSr-Rs-BatCoV strains YNLF_31C and YNLF_34C showed the highest amino acid identities to that of civet SARSr-CoV SZ3. phylogenetic analysis of the ORF8 revealed a distinct clade formed by human/civet SARSr-CoVs and SARSr-Rf-BatCoVs. recombination is key mechanism involved in acquisition of ORF8 by ancestor of civet SARSr-CoVs. previous studies have demonstrated frequent recombination events between SARSr-Rp-BatCoV strains from different bat species of different geographical locations in China. the time of divergence between human/civet and bat SARSr-CoVs ranged from 4 to 17 years before the SARS epidemic (22, 55, 57) previous molecular dating studies estimated that the time of divergence between human/civet and bat SARSr-CoVs ranged from 4 to 17 years before the SARS epidemic. r-BatCoVs and SARS-Rs-BatCoVs are widely distributed throughout china. greater horseshoe bats are also widely distributed across different provinces. they are not found in Guangdong, the province with the highest biodiversity. the ORF8 region, unique to SARSr-CoVs, is prone to mutations or deletions during interspecies transmission. one of the most striking genomic changes observed in SARS-CoV soon after its zoonotic transmission to humans was the acquisition of a characteristic 29-nt deletion which splits ORF8 into two ORFs. the 8b protein downregulates the expression of the E protein, which supports a modulatory role in viral replication (68). overexpression of the 8b protein also plays a role in the host ubiquitin-proteasome system (71). six samples from daubenton's bats (M. daubentonii) contained viruses most closely related to My-BatCoV HKU6. 78 to 99% nucleotide identities in the partial RdRp region. this may represent my-BatCoV HKU6 or related viruses previously reported for the same bat species (38). the two samples from Pomona roundleaf bats contained potentially novel CoVs that are closely related to BatCoV HKU10 or variants of BatCoV HKU10 due to interspecies transmission.
